channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who Would Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate for California? Let the Jockeying Begin
item.description: As the Democratic vice-presidential nominee hits the campaign trail, a race to replace her kicks off.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Senator Kamala Harris is elected vice president, her rise will leave an opening for her seat in the United States Senate.

item.title: Protesters Blocked ICE Buses in Oregon. Federal Agents Responded in Force.
item.description: Using crowd-control weapons, agents were able to extract people who were detained on one of the buses after hundreds of protesters in Bend, Ore., blocked the vehicles from moving.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker

item.title: How Trump’s Push to Reopen Schools Backfired
item.description: Distrust of the president and his motives hardened the conviction of some educators that teaching in person was unsafe, helping drive union opposition.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro
item.media:description: Mr. Trump said the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s guidelines on how to safely reopen schools were “impractical” and should be revised.

item.title: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
item.description: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: More states and cities are moving to require face coverings. In Miami Beach, Fla., above, officials have issued more than $14,000 in fines to people who have refused to wear masks.

item.title: 3 Mississippi Police Officers Charged With Murder of Black Man
item.description: A grand jury indictment accused the officers of pulling George Robinson, 62, from his car in Jackson, Miss., last year, slamming him headfirst into the pavement, and striking and kicking him in the head and the chest.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Marie Fazio
item.media:description: George Robinson, second from right, died after an encounter with the police in Jackson, Miss., in 2019. Three officers have been indicted on murder charges.

item.title: Vanessa Guillen Is Memorialized at Texas Service
item.description: The family of the Army specialist, whose remains were recovered after being reported missing for months from Fort Hood in Texas, remembered her on Friday at a service at her high school.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:description: Soldiers carried the casket of U.S. Army Specialist Vanessa Guillen at her memorial and public viewing at Cesar E. Chavez High School in Houston, on Friday.

item.title: USPS and Mail-In Ballots: States Warned It May Not Meet Deadlines
item.description: The agency suggested allowing at least 15 days to request a ballot, fueling further criticism that it was making it harder to vote during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Hailey Fuchs and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Kamisha Baseden processing mail-in ballots during the primary this month in Renton, Wash.

item.title: Yale Decision: Justice Dept. Ruling Stings Students
item.description: The Trump administration’s charge that the university discriminates against Asian-American applicants was disputed by many Asian-American students and others.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: The Justice Department demanded on Thursday that Yale University, in New Haven, Conn., stop considering race as part of its admissions process.

item.title: TeleTracking Technologies, Firm Running Coronavirus Database, Refuses to Answer Senators' Questions
item.description: A private technology company managing a new coronavirus database said a nondisclosure agreement with the Trump administration blocks it from discussing its $10.2 million contract.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: A list of confirmed Covid-19 cases at the county health department in Salt Lake City. Hospitals were ordered abruptly to stop reporting coronavirus patient data to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and instead send it to TeleTracking Technologies, a private company.

item.title: How Apple’s 30% App Store Cut Became a Boon and a Headache
item.description: App makers like the game company Epic and the music service Spotify are challenging Apple’s right to a large cut of their sales. Regulators have taken notice.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Apple’s take from apps sold in its App Store has become a major part of the company’s business in recent years.

item.title: Expecting at the National Zoo: Washington Hopes to Gain a Baby Panda
item.description: Mei Xiang, a 22-year-old giant panda, has “tissue consistent with fetal development” and could deliver in a few days, according to the zoo.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Mei Xiang has given birth to three surviving cubs, who all live in China.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Hollywood film production is restarting with elaborate precautions to protect the cast and crew.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Senators Criticize Guantánamo Prison Coronavirus Plan
item.description: After a report from the Pentagon, Democrats questioned whether there was enough capacity to help either detainees or their guards if an outbreak occurs.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: A hospital room at Guantánamo Bay includes a shackle point in the floor and an arrow pointing to Mecca. By law, detainees must receive all their medical care on the base.

item.title: President Trump Visits Younger Brother, Robert, in NY Hospital
item.description: Robert S. Trump, the Trump family’s unofficial spokesman and consigliere, is said to be gravely ill.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump with his younger brother, Robert S. Trump, on election night in 2016 in New York.

item.title: Hundreds of SAG-AFTRA Members Will No Longer Qualify for Health Insurance
item.description: The American union for professional film and TV actors told members on Wednesday that it would tighten eligibility requirements and raise premiums. A petition opposing the move has been started.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists
item.media:description: The trustees of the plan “have taken a difficult but necessary action to address financial deficits,” the Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists Health Plan said in a statement.

item.title: U.S. Companies Vie for Funds in Race to Build Rare Earths Industry
item.description: The Trump administration is encouraging development of a domestic industry to produce critical metals now dominated by Chinese companies, but few players show clear long-term promise.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: MP Materials’ mine in Mountain Pass, Calif., is the only operational rare earth mine in the United States.

item.title: Federal Court Rules California's Ban on High-Capacity Magazines Violates 2nd Amendment
item.description: Supporters of tougher gun laws called the ruling a dangerous infringement on the ability of states to protect their residents from mass shootings.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: California’s ban on magazines that hold more than 10 bullets “is so sweeping that half of all magazines in America are now unlawful to own in California,” Judge Kenneth K. Lee wrote.

item.title: Retail Sales Rise for Third Month, Though Growth Slows
item.description: The increase was a sign that consumerism remained resilient, but the recovery has been buoyed by government assistance that expired at the end of July.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:description: Retailers sales rose by 1.2 percent in July, and are now above where they were in February.

item.title: Older Children and the Coronavirus: A New Wrinkle in the Debate
item.description: A new report from South Korea throws into question an earlier finding regarding transmission by older children.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Korean health workers sprayed disinfectant in a classroom in Seoul. Experts said the new data about transmission doesn’t refute the original message, but it underscores the need to consider all evidence when weighing children’s health decisions.

item.title: Principal in Holocaust Dispute Shouldn’t Have Been Fired, Judge Rules
item.description: The Palm Beach County, Fla., school board fired the principal, William Latson, after an email exchange with a parent about Holocaust education came to light.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.category: Spanish River Community High School (Boca Raton, Fla)
item.media:description: William Latson, center, the former principal of Spanish River Community High School, with his attorney Thomas Elfers, right, while waiting for a vote on his termination in 2019.

item.title: Study Says Obesity Raises Risk of Death from Covid-19 Among Men
item.description: Obesity is not an independent risk for women, according to a new study, perhaps because their fat is distributed differently.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Medical workers prepared to transport the body of a patient who died of Covid-19 at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: McConnell Appears Set to Quietly Suffocate Long-Debated F.B.I. Surveillance Bill
item.description: The Senate majority leader has long been a strong supporter of extending Patriot Act provisions. This year, he’s letting them remain lapsed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, has given no sign that he intends to move forward with the legislation when Congress briefly reconvenes after its annual August vacation.

item.title: Top Homeland Security Officials Are Serving Illegally, G.A.O. Says
item.description: The acting secretary of homeland security, Chad F. Wolf, and his deputy, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, were appointed to their posts in violation of federal law, Congress’s watchdog determined.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: The watchdog said the improper appointments, like that of Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, began after Kirstjen Nielsen was forced out of office as the secretary in April 2019.

item.title: John Durham Probe: Ex-FBI Lawyer Expected to Plead Guilty in Review of Russia Inquiry
item.description: Prosecutors did not reveal any evidence of the kind of broad anti-Trump conspiracy among law enforcement officials that the president has long alleged.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: F.B.I. investigators first obtained court permission in October 2016 to wiretap a Trump campaign adviser, and the court agreed to extend the order three times.

item.title: This Star Looked Like It Would Explode. Maybe It Just Sneezed
item.description: The mysterious dimming of the red supergiant Betelgeuse is the result of a stellar exhalation, astronomers say.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: European Southern Observatory/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken in February by the European Southern Observatory’s Very Large Telescope of the star Betelgeuse, in the constellation Orion, which has been observed to be dimming.

item.title: Coronavirus Antibody: Clinical Trials of Drugs Are Taking Longer Than Expected
item.description: Antibody trials sponsored by Regeneron and Eli Lilly are off to a slow start because of a dearth of tests, overwhelmed hospitals and reluctant patients.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monoclonal antibody clinical trial site in Mesa, Ariz., is kept bare to ensure a faster disinfection process. Testing delays, difficulty finding trial sites and challenges to enrolling patients have hindered the research.

item.title: A Black Marxist Scholar Wanted to Talk About Race. It Ignited a Fury.
item.description: The cancellation of a speech reflects an intense debate on the left: Is racism the primary problem in America today, or the outgrowth of a system that oppresses all poor people?
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:description: Adolph Reed teaching a class at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is now a professor emeritus, in April 2019.

item.title: ‘We’ve Already Survived an Apocalypse’: Indigenous Writers Are Changing Sci-Fi
item.description: Long underrepresented in genre fiction, Native American and First Nations authors are reshaping its otherworldly (but still often Eurocentric) worlds.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cherie Dimaline near her home in Midland, Ontario. “There’s a big push now for the telling of Indigenous stories,” she said.

item.title: Luchita Hurtado, Artist Who Became a Sensation in Her 90s, Dies at 99
item.description: For years she worked in the shadow of her artist husbands and more famous peers, painting at night when the children were asleep. Then a trove of her work was discovered.
item.dc:creator: Karen Rosenberg
item.media:description: The artist Luchita Hurtado with some of her work in 2018. Her work spanned Surrealism, Mexican muralism, feminism and environmentalism.

item.title: Michael Cohen releases details about his forthcoming memoir.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:description: Michael D. Cohen upon his return home from prison in July.

item.title: How to Vote by Mail in California
item.description: Friday: Although Californians have a leg up, turning out voters during a pandemic will still be a challenge. Also: The jockeying for Kamala Harris’s seat has begun.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A man casting his ballot on the eve of Super Tuesday, at a voting center in Sacramento in March.

item.title: Who from California would replace Kamala Harris in the Senate?
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Kamala Harris is elected vice president, her rise will leave an opening for her Senate seat.

item.title: Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory against Harris.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Trump at a news briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Urges Mandatory Masks, and Trump Pushes Birtherism
item.description: And Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Trump vs. the Post Office
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:description: Sarah Miler sorting ballots for Washington State’s primary last week.

item.title: Firm Helping Run U.S. Coronavirus Database Refuses Senators’ Questions
item.description: People who recover from the virus have a three-month window of safety, C.D.C. guidance shows. The U.S. Postal Service warned several states that it may not be able to meet deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots.

item.title: The Women Who Fought Against the Vote
item.description: To understand the suffragists, and why their battle took so long, you also have to understand the anti-suffragists.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

item.title: In Prison, Learning Magic by Mail
item.description: A deck of cards cut from milk cartons. A wand made with medical tape. How a group of inmates learned “the magic of magic.”
item.dc:creator: Annalisa Quinn and Vincent Tullo
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: Fighting for the Vote With Cartoons
item.description: Cartoonists used the press to battle anti-suffrage stereotypes and create a new image for the movement to enfranchise women.
item.dc:creator: Anna Diamond

item.title: Tackling a Century-Old Mystery: Did My Grandmother Vote?
item.description: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.
item.dc:creator: Martha S. Jones

item.title: Families Priced Out of Coronavirus ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives
item.description: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shy Rodriguez with her sons, Shawn Pagan, 11, left, and Jaiden Pagan, 8, at their home in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Ms. Rodriguez has been trying to recruit other parents for a “pool” that would share child care responsibilities.

item.title: Coronavirus: When Will Long-Term Care Facilities Reopen to Visitors?
item.description: Struck hard by the pandemic, long-term and assisted living facilities shut their doors to outsiders. Many still have not reopened.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cathy Baum, right, and her husband, Mark, visited her mother, Paulette Becker, at Tall Oaks Assisted Living in Reston, Va., earlier this month.

item.title: How Queer Women Powered the Suffrage Movement
item.description: For many suffragists, scholars have found, the freedom to choose whom and how they loved was tied deeply to the idea of voting rights.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: How 14 Elephant Seals Assisted an Antarctic Ice Study
item.description: Mapping currents in the Southern Ocean is vital to monitoring climate change, but hard to conduct. So scientists turned to seals for help.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: A male southern elephant seal on South Georgia Island. The seals have become scientific collaborators, helping track under-ice ocean currents in Antarctica’s marginal ice zone.
